answers.answer: Might help us help you find a good thyroid doctor if you will give us a clue as to where you are located.  LOL  Note I said a good thyroid doctor.  That does not necessarily mean an Endo.  Endos frequently specialize in diabetes, not thyroid.  Also, many Endos have the "Immaculate TSH Belief" and only want to diagnose and treat based on TSH.  Does not work.  If they go beyond TSH it is usually only to test for Free T4 and then use "Reference range Endocrinology", by which they will tell you that a Free T4 taht falls anywheree within the range is adequate.  Also wrong.  A godo thyroid doctor will treat a hypo patient clinically by testing and adjusting Free T3 and Free T4 as necessary to relieve symptoms, without being constrained by resultant TSH levels.  Symptoms should be all important, not just test results, and especially not TSH.How about posting your thyroid related test results and reference ranges shown on the lab report.  Also tell us bout symptoms you have.

Guess it would help to know where I am. Brain fart. I am in KC. I guess you could say am I on sort of a fishing expedition.  I have cholinergic urticaria and am losing hair by the handful since November.  Trouble sleeping, tired all the time. Thyroid problems run in my family and I figured I would start with someone who would look at more than just t3, t4, free t4. That's all my PCP will do.
I just sent you a PM with doctor info.  To access, just click on your name and then from your personal page, click on messages.

question: I, too, am looking for a good endocrinologist.
title: help
